ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
What is your overall rating of the primary instructor?
The primary instructor's sensitivity to students and ability to provide students with adequate feedback was:

narratives.question_text: Indicate the total number of hours per week (outside the classroom) you spent on this course:
comments: 5 to 6
4 hours
3-5 hours for critique writing 6-8 hours on paper presentation 6-8 hours on final paper/presentation

narratives.question_text: Looking back on this course, what is your overall assessment of the course:  What are its strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might it be improved?
comments: Good. I learned how to critique scientific articles and learned the scientific basis and background of parasitic diseases that affect the world today.
it is perfect!
Vary diversified and great topics, speakers and papers selected for discussion. Creative final project.

Loved how it was laid out. One thing I would have enjoyed would be more of those jeopardy like quizzes to reinforce the fundamentals from each lectures. Really liked the critical papers, but sometimes I felt like I was forgetting the basics of the parasites because I was too busy writing the papers and didn't have much time to just study the material.

I really enjoyed this course. Though my background is in invert bio and parasitic infections are one of my specialty areas, I learned a lot from the course material. This class improved my ability to critique scientific articles in writing and discussion days promoted an engaging atmosphere. Both professors were also more than willing to explain unfamiliar or difficult concepts or consult about readings that were dense or hard to understand. They always contributed to class discussion and were frank and open about their experiences as academic researchers. The feedback we received on written assignments was always specific and constructive, and my grades on critiques improved as the semester progressed because of it! This course also made discussing and critiquing scientific papers less intimidating and afforded a great opportunity to sometimes speak directly with the paper authors themselves. The final project was a fun exercise that allowed for some creativity. I got to see an interesting variety of proposals from my classmates in other disciplines. Overall a fantastic course!

Really enjoyed it and at the same time I learned a lot. I feel a lot more confident in my ability to critique published research. I am really happy with the amount I learned about parasites and am inspired to learn more.

narratives.question_text: Please evaluate the instructor of this course. What are the instructor's strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might his or her teaching be improved?
comments: Instructor: Christian Tschudi  Great professor.
Instructor: Christian Tschudi  he is awesome
Instructor: Christian Tschudi  Fun great professor. appreciated papers he selected for discussion.
Instructor: Christian Tschudi  excellent - very approachable
Instructor: Christian Tschudi  Really enjoyed his lectures and discussions. It was a pleasure to learn from him.
Instructor: Diane McMahon-Pratt  Great professor.
Instructor: Diane McMahon-Pratt  she is great.
Instructor: Diane McMahon-Pratt  great professor very clear and professional.
Instructor: Diane McMahon-Pratt  excellent - very approachable

Instructor: Diane McMahon-Pratt  Really fantastic, so knowledgeable and supported interesting discussions and student discovery. I would have liked a few more comments on the critiques or a longer review of how to write them better.

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize this course for a fellow student? Would you recommend it to another student? Why or why not?
comments: Definitely take this class. You will learn more about various parasitic diseases and learn how to critique scientific papers. Great class overall.
This is a very interactive course. Great material and lot to learn. Totally recommend it!
Fun class if you want to get a feel of the cutting age research in parasitology.

Casual, but exciting and stimulating. Would really recommend if you are interested in getting better at critically reading scientific literature that maybe out of your comfort zone. The diversity of the students (all in different departments) was really fun. People gave much different insights on things depending on their background.

Whether or not you're interested in parasitology, this course is a great forum for practicing critiques and discussing scientific papers. The professors are wonderful, and you'll get a great overview of a variety of parasitic infections through multiple public health lenses.
This course is an excellent to both learn about parasites and how to critique research. You learn a lot but at the same time are not overloaded with busy work. I absolutely recommend this class!
